There was “Truth by Ordeal” - great fun for all involved….  If you were accused of a crime, you either confessed or were subjected to a test such as drowning. This was the judicial method of determining innocence or guilt - truth or falsehood - before there were judges, juries, and evidence. In trial by ordeal, the expectation - or pretense - was that God would intervene in the outcome if the accused were innocent. The most common test was ordeal by hot water, in which the accused had to reach into a pot of perhaps boiling water and retrieve an object. It was up to the priest to determine how hot the water was, so the verdict could be a forgone conclusion. (You know the expression “in hot water”.)  In the ordeal by hot iron, the accused person would carry a burning hot iron so many paces without being burned to prove their innocence. Again the priest could rig the outcome. Alternatively, there was trial by fire - a familiar expression. This required the accused to walk a certain distance over red-hot plowshares (metal blades). In ordeal by cold water if the person were innocent they would sink, and if they were guilty they would float - that’s not the wrong way round. If the priest considered you innocent, you might be instructed to struggle in order to ensure sinking. The sinking individual was not left to drown (which would have made it a “heads you're guilty, tails you're dead” test). [1] Of course, there were other ordeals that were as sadistic as they sound, such as by cross (actually not crucifixion), by burning oil, and by poison. Universities existed as they were all founded & run by Catholic Jesuits & Cathusians. They were not as backward as some might imagine. Apothecary was out of its infancy. Most hospitals & infirmaries were run by & located at monasteries. Is where the names 'nurse' & ward 'sister' came from, because sisters were literally religious sisters. Scientific research was well under way (like to see the monk priest defrocked who turned gun-powder into expellents). The scientific method: if a theory could be replicated then it was held to be true. Experimentation with mixing ferrous & non-ferrous metals & testing for tensile strength. Principles later to be used in the construction of canon barrels & printing presses. Heavy iron carriage wheels became light but more durable wheels. Non- ferrous alloys for intricate engineering, the principles later used in making clockwork mechanisms & coaching suspensions were being researched, well ahead of industrial revolution. Principles of ballistics, were modelled.wight to range ratios of shot & distance to calibre ratios. Straight v spinning projectiles was becoming a science in its own right. Mixing antimony with tin & lead (other materials) to make solder. They discovered that a 40% tin content gave the longest period of placisity so the materials had longer to be worked, particularly useful for leading around glass for large church, school & manor windows. Chemistry & pesticides were being discovered & Grinding glass for opthalmics albeit primitive was well under way. Even primitive principles of flight were being discovered. How naturally occuring colours in nature long since used for dyes, mixing in other naturally occuring substances to improve durability & improve longevity of dyes. Evolving scientific methods of experimentation. So they were not as primitive as many would like to think. Peace & All Good

Truth was discovered through the scholastic method, that is ultimately derived from some authority, e.g. a renowned author, church father, one’s priest, lord, father, husband, etc. Empiricism did not yet exist and it wouldn’t be allowed anyway - too threatening to the medieval social order.
